name.text: Determining Positions of Points with Respect to a Given Circle

questiontext.text:
Consider a circle of radius \({@radius@}\) whose center is at \(O({@c_x@},{@c_y@})\). Determine whether each of the following points is on the circle, inside the circle or outside the circle by first calculating the distance.

1. \(P_1({@p_1_x@},{@p_1_y@}) \)

Distance \(=\) [[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

The point \(P_1\) lies [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

2. \(P_2({@p_2_x@},{@p_2_y@}) \)

Distance \(=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

The point \(P_2\) lies [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

3. \(P_3({@p_3_x@},{@p_3_y@}) \)

Distance \(=\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]][[feedback:prt5]]

The point \(P_3\) lies [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]][[feedback:prt6]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

To determine whether each point is on the circle, inside the circle, or outside the circle, we can use the distance formula between each point and the center of the circle. If the distance between the point and the center is equal to the radius, the point lies on the circle. If it's less than the radius, the point is inside the circle, and if it's greater than the radius, the point is outside the circle.

Let's calculate the distance for each point:

1. Point \( P_1({@p_1_x@},{@p_1_y@}) \)

\( \begin{align} \text{Distance} \displaystyle & =\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_1_x@}-({@c_x@}))^2+({@p_1_y@}-({@c_y@}))^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_1_x-c_x@})^2+({@p_1_y-c_y@})^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{ {@(p_1_x-c_x)^2@}+{@(p_1_y-c_y)^2@} } \\ &= \sqrt{ {@(p_1_x-c_x)^2+(p_1_y-c_y)^2@} } [[ if test='integerp(sqrt((p_1_x-c_x)^2+(p_1_y-c_y)^2))' ]] \\ &= { {@sqrt((p_1_x-c_x)^2+(p_1_y-c_y)^2)@} } [[/ if]] \end{align} \)

[[ if test='ta1=radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta1@}\) is equal to the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_1\) lies on the circle. [[ elif test='ta1>radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta1@}\) is greater than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_1\) lies outside the circle.

[[ else ]]

Since the distance \({@ta1@}\) is less than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_1\) lies inside the circle.

[[/ if]]

2. Point \( P_2({@p_2_x@},{@p_2_y@}) \)

\( \begin{align} \text{Distance} \displaystyle & =\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_2_x@}-({@c_x@}))^2+({@p_2_y@}-({@c_y@}))^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_2_x-c_x@})^2+({@p_2_y-c_y@})^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{ {@(p_2_x-c_x)^2@}+{@(p_2_y-c_y)^2@} } \\ &= \sqrt{ {@(p_2_x-c_x)^2+(p_2_y-c_y)^2@} } [[ if test='integerp(sqrt((p_2_x-c_x)^2+(p_2_y-c_y)^2))' ]] \\ &= { {@sqrt((p_2_x-c_x)^2+(p_2_y-c_y)^2)@} } [[/ if]] \end{align} \)

[[ if test='ta2=radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta2@}\) is equal to the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_2\) lies on the circle.

[[ elif test='ta2>radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta2@}\) is greater than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_2\) lies outside the circle.

[[ else ]]

Since the distance \({@ta2@}\) is less than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_2\) lies inside the circle.

[[/ if]]

3. Point \( P_3({@p_3_x@},{@p_3_y@}) \)

\( \begin{align} \text{Distance} \displaystyle & =\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_3_x@}-({@c_x@}))^2+({@p_3_y@}-({@c_y@}))^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{({@p_3_x-c_x@})^2+({@p_3_y-c_y@})^2 } \\ &=\sqrt{ {@(p_3_x-c_x)^2@}+{@(p_3_y-c_y)^2@} } \\ &= \sqrt{ {@(p_3_x-c_x)^2+(p_3_y-c_y)^2@} } [[ if test='integerp(sqrt((p_3_x-c_x)^2+(p_3_y-c_y)^2))' ]] \\ &= { {@sqrt((p_3_x-c_x)^2+(p_3_y-c_y)^2)@} } [[/ if]] \end{align} \)

[[ if test='ta3=radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta3@}\) is equal to the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_3\) lies on the circle.

[[ elif test='ta3>radius' ]]

Since the distance \({@ta3@}\) is greater than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_3\) lies outside the circle.

[[ else ]]

Since the distance \({@ta3@}\) is less than the radius \( {@radius@} \) , point \(P_3\) lies inside the circle.

[[/ if]]

A circle of radius \({@radius@}\) whose center is at \(C({@c_x@},{@c_y@})\).

1. \(P_1({@p_1_x@},{@p_1_y@}) \)

Distance \(={@ta1@}\)

The point \(P_1\) lie \({@mcq_correct(ta_1)[1]@}\)

2. \(P_2({@p_2_x@},{@p_2_y@}) \)

Distance \(={@ta2@}\)

The point \(P_2\) lie \({@mcq_correct(ta_2)[1]@}\)

3. \(P_3({@p_3_x@},{@p_3_y@}) \)

Distance \(={@ta3@}\)

The point \(P_3\) lie \({@mcq_correct(ta_3)[1]@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
